text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
and CNBC with one week of Democratic
primary campaigning left one issue looms
over the endgame between Barack Obama
and Hillary Clinton
it's whether Obama can attract enough
support from a key constituency white
working-class voters to win in November
Hillary Clinton's raising doubts
pointing to her huge margins among this
group in states like Ohio Pennsylvania
Indiana in Kentucky her argument is that
Obama's weakness in the primary signals
weakness against John McCain this fall
but one of the leading experts on
blue-collar Democrats doesn't buy it rui
Teixeira who co-authored a book
subtitled why the white working-class
still matters argues that Obama
currently stands just where he needs to
be to win now how could that be well to
begin with Teixeira says the choices
that so-called NASCAR dads and waitress
moms make between popular Democrats and
party primaries are bad evidence for
what they'll do when Obama faces
Republican nominee John McCain second
Obama doesn't need to win among white
working-class voters who shrunk as a
proportion of the information age
economy and of the Democratic base he
just needs to avoid losing them by too
much if you can hold his deficit down to
around 10 or 12 percentage points the
way House Democrats did in their 2006
midterm election win Teixeira says he
can beat McCain and in two recent
national surveys that's exactly what
he's doing a Quinnipiac University poll
showed Obama trailing by seven
percentage points among white
working-class voters defined as those
without college degrees a Washington
post/abc News poll showed him trailing
by 12 points overall both surveys show
Obama ahead of McCain nationally by 7
points of course the Electoral College
is what counts in the end Clinton
strategists say Obama's weakness among
working-class voters could keep him from
winning Florida where polls show she
leaves McCain while Obama trails and
Republicans say white working-class
voters in states like Michigan and
Missouri feel a cultural distance from
an Ivy league-educated Democrat who
would be the first African American
president but for now it appears Obama
is faring better with those voters than
John Kerry who lost them by 23
percentage points in his narrow loss to
President Bush four years ago rui
tashera's conclusion obama has a problem
with white working-class voters but it's
a solvable four
